maml:description.maml:para: Connect to Intune
A separate command to select the correct authentication provider, you no longer have to provide the auth parameters with each command.
Use a username to trigger interactive login or SSO
Disable Windows authentication broker
Specify the tenant ID, optional. Loaded from `AZURE_TENANT_ID`
Specify the alternative client ID, optional. Loaded from `AZURE_CLIENT_ID`
Specify the scopes to request, default is `DeviceManagementConfiguration.ReadWrite.All`, `DeviceManagementApps.ReadWrite.All`
Immediately try to get a token.
Use a managed identity to connect to Intune
Specify the scopes to request, default is `https://graph.microsoft.com/.default`
Immediately try to get a token.
Use default Azure Credentials from Azure.Identity to connect to Intune
Specify the scopes to request, default is `https://graph.microsoft.com/.default`
Immediately try to get a token.
Use a token from another source to connect to Intune, this is the least preferred way to use
Specify the client ID, mandatory for Client Credentials flow. Loaded from `AZURE_CLIENT_ID`
Specify the client secret. Loaded from `AZURE_CLIENT_SECRET`
Specify the tenant ID. Loaded from `AZURE_TENANT_ID`
Specify the scopes to request, default is `https://graph.microsoft.com/.default`
Immediately try to get a token.
Use a managed identity to connect to Intune
Use default Azure Credentials from Azure.Identity to connect to Intune
Use a token from another source to connect to Intune, this is the least preferred way to use
Disable Windows authentication broker
Use a username to trigger interactive login or SSO
Specify the tenant ID, optional. Loaded from `AZURE_TENANT_ID`
Specify the client ID, mandatory for Client Credentials flow. Loaded from `AZURE_CLIENT_ID`
Specify the client secret. Loaded from `AZURE_CLIENT_SECRET`
Specify the scopes to request, default is `https://graph.microsoft.com/.default`
Immediately try to get a token.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This will trigger a login broker popup (Windows Hello) on Windows and the default browser on other platforms
Try to connect using a managed identity on the current platform, obviously only works in Azure.
A chain of credentials is tried until one succeeds. Including Environment Variables, Managed Identity, Visual Studio (code) and Azure CLI

maml:description.maml:para: Create a MsStore app in Intune

Use this command to create an Microsoft Store app in Microsoft Intune.\r\n\r\nThis is an [**authenticated command**](./authentication), so call [Connect-WtWinTuner](./Connect-WtWinTuner) before calling this command.
The package id to upload to Intune.
Categories to add to the app
Groups that the app should available for, Group Object ID or `AllUsers` / `AllDevices`
Groups that the app is required for, Group Object ID or `AllUsers` / `AllDevices`
Groups that the app should be uninstalled for, Group Object ID or `AllUsers` / `AllDevices`
Name of the app to look for, first match will be created.
Categories to add to the app
Groups that the app should available for, Group Object ID or `AllUsers` / `AllDevices`
Groups that the app is required for, Group Object ID or `AllUsers` / `AllDevices`
Groups that the app should be uninstalled for, Group Object ID or `AllUsers` / `AllDevices`
The package id to upload to Intune.
Name of the app to look for, first match will be created.
Categories to add to the app
Groups that the app should available for, Group Object ID or `AllUsers` / `AllDevices`
Groups that the app is required for, Group Object ID or `AllUsers` / `AllDevices`
Groups that the app should be uninstalled for, Group Object ID or `AllUsers` / `AllDevices`
Microsoft.Graph.Beta.Models.WinGetApp

dev:remarks.maml:para: Add Firefox to Intune and make available for `AllUsers`

maml:description.maml:para: Create a Win32Lob app in Intune

Use this command to upload an intunewin package to Microsoft Intune as a new Win32LobApp.\r\n\r\nThis is an [**authenticated command**](./authentication), so call [Connect-WtWinTuner](./Connect-WtWinTuner) before calling this command.
The package id to upload to Intune.
The version to upload to Intune
The Root folder where all the package live in.
Categories to add to the app
Groups that the app should available for, Group Object ID or `AllUsers` / `AllDevices`
Groups that the app is required for, Group Object ID or `AllUsers` / `AllDevices`
Groups that the app should be uninstalled for, Group Object ID or `AllUsers` / `AllDevices`
Graph ID of the app to supersede
Override the name of the app in Intune
The App configuration you want to create
The .intunewin file that should be added to this app
Load the logo from file

Groups that the app should be uninstalled for, Group Object ID or `AllUsers` / `AllDevices`
Graph ID of the app to supersede
Override the name of the app in Intune
The folder where the package is

dev:remarks.maml:para: OhMyPosh v19.5.0 is packaged to this folder, now deploy it to Azure

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ Package and deploy OhMyPosh -------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-WtWingetPackage -PackageId JanDeDobbeleer.OhMyPosh -PackageFolder C:\Tools\Packages | Deploy-WtWin32App -Available AllUsers

dev:remarks.maml:para: Combining both the `New-WtWinGetPackage` and the `Deploy-WtWin32App` command, and making it available to All Users

maml:description.maml:para: Clear authentication data from module
You can call Connect-WtWinTuner which will keep security things in memory, to be able to clear things we made this command

dev:remarks.maml:para: This will remove all credentials from the memory

maml:description.maml:para: Get a token for graph

This command will get a token for the graph api. The token is cached, so you can call this as often as you want.\r\n\r\nThis is an [**authenticated command**](./authentication), so call [Connect-WtWinTuner](./Connect-WtWinTuner) before calling this command.
Decode the token
Output the token to the logs?
Decode the token
Output the token to the logs?
System.String

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get token, show details and copy to clipboard

maml:description.maml:para: Get all apps from Intune packaged by WinTuner

Load apps from Tenant and filter based on Update available.\r\n\r\nThis is an [**authenticated command**](./authentication), so call [Connect-WtWinTuner](./Connect-WtWinTuner) before calling this command.
Filter based on UpdateAvailable
Filter based on SupersedingAppCount
Filter based on SupersedingAppCount
Filter based on UpdateAvailable
Filter based on SupersedingAppCount
Filter based on SupersedingAppCount
Svrooij.WinTuner.CmdLets.Models.WtWin32App[]

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get all apps that have updates available

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------------- Update apps ---------------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $updatedApps = Get-WtWin32Apps -Update $true -Superseded $false foreach($app in $updatedApps) { New-WtWingetPackage -PackageId $($app.PackageId) -PackageFolder $rootPackageFolder -Version $($app.LatestVersion) | Deploy-WtWin32App -GraphId $($app.GraphId) }

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get all apps that have be an update available and are not superseeded. This executes the [New-WtWingetPackage](./New-WtWingetPackage) command. You could run this on a weekly bases.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Remove superseeded apps ---------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $oldApps = Get-WtWin32Apps -Superseded $true foreach($app in $oldApps) { Remove-WtWin32App -AppId $app.GraphId }

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get all apps that have been superseeded and remove them. This executes the [Remove-WtWin32App](./Remove-WtWin32App) command. You could run this on a weekly bases.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new IntuneWin package
This is a re-implementation of the IntuneWinAppUtil.exe tool, it's not feature complete use at your own risk.
The directory containing all the installation files
The main setupfile in the source directory
Destination folder, should be outside the source folder
The directory containing all the installation files
The main setupfile in the source directory
Destination folder, should be outside the source folder

command:example.maml:title: ---------------------------------- Example -----------------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-IntuneWinPackage -SourcePath C:\Temp\Source -SetupFile C:\Temp\Source\setup.exe -DestinationPath C:\Temp\Destination

dev:remarks.maml:para: Package all files in `C:\Temp\Source`, with setup file `..\setup.exe` to the specified folder

maml:description.maml:para: Create intunewin file from Winget installer
Downloads the installer for the package and creates an `.intunewin` file for uploading in Intune.
The package id to download
The folder to store the package in
The version to download (optional)
The folder to store temporary files in
Pick this architecture
The installer context
Package WinGet script, instead of the actual installer. Helpful for installers that don't really work with WinTuner.
The desired locale, if available (eg. 'en-US')
Override the installer arguments

The folder to store the package in

dev:remarks.maml:para: Package the latest version of `JanDeDobbeleer.OhMyPosh` to `C:\tools\packages`. The package will be in `C:\tools\packages\{packageId}\{version}`

maml:description.maml:para: Remove an app from Intune

Will remove the relationships (if any) first and then remove the app.\r\n\r\nThis is an [**authenticated command**](./authentication), so call [Connect-WtWinTuner](./Connect-WtWinTuner) before calling this command.
Id of the app in Intune
Id of the app in Intune

dev:remarks.maml:para: Delete a single app by ID, mind the quotes around the ID!

maml:description.maml:para: Search for packages in WinGet
Search for WinGet packages, but faster. This uses the an [online index](https://wintuner.app/docs/related/winget-package-index).
Part of the package ID, 2 characters minimum
Part of the package ID, 2 characters minimum
Winget.CommunityRepository.Models.WingetEntry

dev:remarks.maml:para: Searching in the online index, by a part of the package id.
